content.RichText: {\rtf1\ansi {\fonttbl\f0\fnil Monospaced;\f1\fnil Dialog;\f2\fnil Arial;\f3\fnil Symbol;} {\colortbl\red0\green0\blue0;\red51\green51\blue51;} \margl1417\margr1417\margt1417\margb1417\widowctrl \li0\ri0\fi0\sb120\f2\fs24\i0\b0\ul0\cf0 You have seen the physicians that were monitoring Morgan\rquote s health in \lquote Super Size Me\rquote measuring his heart rate and blood pressure. These values might provide information about a person\rquote s health. Even though we are not physicians, and therefore cannot make a reliable medical interpretation, it might be interesting to measure our heart rate as well.\par \par Heart rate is measured in beats per minute (bpm). You probably know that your heart beats a lot faster when you are exercising. For the health passport we need the resting heart rate. This is the heart rate when a person is awake, but not doing any physical work. A healthy resting heart rate will be somewhere in between 60 and 80 bpm for adults. For teenagers, the outer limits of this healthy range are set even further apart. Resting heart rates of 90 bpm are no exception. But heart rates below 60 bpm are also common, especially if you exercise regularly.\par \par \i Measuring your own heart rate\i0\par There are a number of places on your body where you can feel your own pulse. A good place to start looking for it would be your neck, where you probably will be able to find the pulse of the so called carotid artery just below your chin.\par \li720\fi-360\tx720\f3\'b7\tab\f2 Sit down and relax your muscles. Place two fingers of one hand just below your chin and try to find your pulse. Hold a stopwatch in your other hand. Once you have found your pulse, start the stopwatch and count the number of heartbeats for one minute.\par \f3\'b7\tab\f2 Ask two of your fellow students to measure your heart rate as well.\par \f3\'b7\tab\f2 Calculate the average of these three measurements. This value will be a reasonably good estimate of your heart rate.\par \pard\li0\ri0\fi0\f1\ul0\cf1\par }
